Title: BloodyCheckers

Article (copied content): Now let's get into the root of the review,  
BloodyCheckers. This game has to be my absolute favorite XNA Indie Game on
 
the marketplace. For 80 Microsoft Points this is a steal! You start off on
 
top of a mountain looking at a towering castle in the darkness of night.
It  
begins with you reading a note explaining how you got there and a little  
bit about the story. After reading the note you must venture into the  
castle. Before you do so though, look around, observe not only the ground 

around you but look at the beautiful night sky, the brilliant shadowing on
 
the castle.. the creator clearly put a lot of time and effort into making 

this game just right visually. Also, the game has the absolute best head  
bobble animation I've ever seen just for another.. random plus to the
game.

After heading inside and walking around a bit, perhaps opening a chest or 

two you soon discover that there are pictures of strange... dead people on
 
the walls. By interacting with these dead people's pictures (with your  
candle lit) you can read a little about how they died and fight them! How 

do you fight them? With a good old fashion game of checkers? Nope! Well,  
kind of. In BloodyCheckers you get extra little goodies in the matches
such  
as setting traps and spells, firing arrows at your targets, and even..
rage  
quitting. Yes that's right you heard, rage quitting. Smashing the board in
 
half out of pure frustration has finally been implemented into a video  
board game.

I don't want to spoil anything and since the storyline is relatively short
 
seeing as it's an Indie game I can't really talk about it without giving  
away anything.. so sadly you are going to find another review or watch a  
YouTube video for the storyline. Though what I can tell you is this, you  
play through an epic multi-level dungeon style medieval castle fighting  
your way past both real live foes via burning them to bits and dead people
 
in bloody checkers games in order to save a King and a Queen.

Overall for 80 Microsoft Points this is a game like no other and is  
definitely worth the $1.00! When it comes down to it for its genre I give 

it a 9/10.
